OLIVER
This mini male Eskie is about 19 lbs. He is 90% white with some biscuit color along his spinal area to his tail. 
He is around 3 to 4 yrs old, and full of life and energy. He will need a fenced yard and another dog to play with. A dog his size would be perfect.  He has a little alpha in him, and he will try to dominate a smaller dog. 
If you have older children that know how to respect a dog, then Oliver could be the perfect addition to any family.
We do not know about cats, so not sure how he would react to them?  He is not mean, but he may chase them like it was a game. 
He likes to run up to you and jump into your arms to give you kisses. 
He is fostered in the Cincinnati, OH area - so if you are interested in adopting him - you will have to come to Ohio to meet him and us.   
Please  email us at ohioeskierescue@outlook.com for an application.

PATRICK is so sweet and so insecure.  Poor little guy was neglected and possibly abused. We are working on his confidence and putting some weight on the little guy. You can feel his ribs and vertebrae.  He likes to be carried around and wants to sit with you on the couch.  He likes other dogs, he doesn't really play with them, but will go run around the yard with them. If interested in PATRICK, email us at OhioEskieRescue@outlook.com.
He is fully vetted, neutered, house trained, around 5yrs old. Fostered in the Cincinnati Ohio area.

We at Ohio American Eskimo are always looking for foster parents for the dogs we save from local shelters and owners surrenders.  If you are interested please contact us on Facebook or email us at ohioeskierescue@outlook.com.  Than kyou

Meet our Patrick! He is 5 yrs old. He came to the rescue from an Ohio shelter. He was only 12 lbs and very sick. He is up to 18lbs and still has some respiratory issues due to his illness. He is on meds and doing great. He loves to be at your side. He also loves to eat or munch some veggies with you. He is a people person, and will get along great with other dogs, but prefers your lap. Just don't' expect him to play with other dogs. He probably would do well with cats. Email us at ohioeskierescue@outlook.com for an application

Trig  turned 1 year old on November 26, 2017. He is fully vetted, 23lbs. He is a small standard Eskie. Trig is a very active puppy, so he would like a family who would enjoy doing activities with him. Trig loves to run and chase balls. He also loves a good game of tug. Trig did not have many advantages as a puppy mill boy, so he would do best as an only dog in a home with no cats or young children. He loves pets, giving kisses and sleeping on the bed with you at night. He love people. If you are interested in this wonderful boy contact Ohio American Eskimo Rescue @ ohioeskierescue@outlook.com Fostered in Columbus.

Our American Eskimo and Siberian Husky mix pooch is up for adoption with Ohio American Eskimo Rescue. He is neutered, fully vetted, and microchipped. 

A note from his foster Mom. 

Champ is a 7 year old Huskimo from an Ohio Puppy Mill. He is the most beautiful pup I have ever seen. When he came to my home he was very stressed because he did not understand his surroundings. Champ has come a long ways with his 6 foster siblings. Our routine is down, he sleeps on the side of me beside the bed and if he wants up he takes my blanket off. Haha! Gives me a kiss and then we go outside and do our buisness. He jumps around because breakfast is getting prepared. Champ will go back outside to hang out for a bit and come back in and lay around. He is a really laid back dog. Loves the other dogs, not really playful, maybe because they are small. He sure knows that his Foster Mom loves him, we have hugging times that he just loves. I have tried to teach him to howl, but nothing works, yes I am a little crazy. We are still working on his peeing in the house, which is really rare as long as I am on top of him going out. He never pooped in the house. As long as you are sitting down to his level with your hand out and let him come to you, he is great around strangers. He just runs in the other room and will watch TV( LOVES IT) He does not have a mean bone in his body.Champ deserves a family that will give him time to decompress and he will be the best dog????

Please email us at ohioeskierescue@outlook.com for an application. 

Fostered in the Syracuse, NY area.

TRINITY joined us on Easter Sunday from a county shelter here in Ohio.  She is very vocal and stressed right now, so we are not sure if that is a permanent trait in her.  She is very loving, very outgoing, and gets along great with other dogs.  She is not fond of a leash, and loves to do the Eskie zoom around the yard.   We would like a fenced yard for her.

MAX â (1.5 yrs old) he is high energy, so he needs an avid runner or a huge yard to run his laps.  He can be a little too playful with smaller dogs, so a bigger dog would be a great buddy to him.  He is a standard Eskie weighing about 30lbs.  He needs a slow introduction to most people especially men.  Once he warms out, look out, he is jumping on you for lots of love.  He will whine to go outside, he will whine for treat, he will whine for dinner time. He is not shy about showing what he wants.  He is fostered near Cincinnati.  We are not sure about cats, he needs older kids.   He is house trained

Grace â she is a small 13lb, female Eskie. She is a survivor of the mills of Ohio. She is very shy and must have been attacked by another dog at the mill. She is warming up to the males in the house, but she will not do well with an obnoxious dog. She would be fine with a mellow dog.  Grace has to see you most of the time and be with you. She has severe separation anxiety, so no apartment life for her. She does not know how to go up/down steps, but she is learning. She has to sleep in bed with you, right near your body.  She is doing really well learning about house training. She has learned to bark for dinner time.  She is fostered near Cincinnati, OH   Not sure about cats, would probably ignore them.  I would not put her with kids because they would not understand her or give her the proper attention.  She is good with meeting new people, but skittish. .  We prefer an adopter who knows mill dogs.

*Charity - 2 yr old female Eskie joined us on January 11th from an Ohio puppy mill. She is very sweet but very scared. She needs a gentle hand and voice to show her to trust humans. She is good with other dogs. She had a dental, spayed, all tests and shots.
Look at this wonderful face! Our Charity if a survivor of the puppy mills of Ohio. She is 2 yrs old, and so full of life. She is scared at first but when she starts to trust you, she will be your best friend. She likes other dogs, people, cats, you name it, she will be friends!. She loves to run and has not had a lot of leash training. So we would like to have a fenced yard for this girl so she can run like the wind.

I am a spunky 50 pound Senior named Grady! Born at the end of July, 2006, I am happy, healthy, but suddenly homeless for the first time in my life. Due to human circumstances, my world has changed and I am hoping for a new place to hang my leash. I love walks, car rides, sunning on the porch. Well-mannered, I am an affectionate housedog. I like dogs and well-behaved childrenâand a comfortable couch! I would be happiest in a calm, quiet household. Fully vetted, my adoption fee is $100. For an application, send a message to caninematchmaker@yahoo.com and/or call 317-523-4785 and leave a message. Looking forward to meeting you! 4/11/18 4:17 PM

Mufasa looks like a little bear and not a lion!  He was found as a stray in rural KY and we estimate him to have been born about November 2015.  He was most likely used as a farm dog and without secure fencing and strayed away.  He is a friendly boy with a lot of puppy in him. He lves to play and like to follow you too.  He is friendly and gets along well with other dogs. He could be mixed with American Eskimo, his tail curls over his back.  He won't be a big mature male, maybe about 70 Lbs. He does have more of the Eskie attitude of being in  charge, but also has the calmness of a pyr.   Mufasa will be placed as an inside pet with outside privileges to  a secure visibly fenced  yard.  Pyrs do not do well with wireless fencing.  We recommend obedience training for all newly adopted pyrs, to help you create a special bond with you and your new friend, and so you have a well behaved canine.  Great Pyrenees are willing to learn, but are not as eager to comply with commands as much as other breeds.  They are bred to be independent thinkers.Adopters must be over 25, own their own home and  he  would do best with an adult only home with  children in household over 16years old.   If you are interested in giving Mufasa a foster or a  forever home, please go to our website and complete the appropriate application. www.igpr.org
Adoption fee is $300

All of our dogs marked as needing foster homes are also available for adoption. In fostering a dog, the dog comes to you fully vetted. and groomed.  You provide good quality food,  grooming, and we provide the heartworm preventative and medical care, if needed* .(*Based on approval from IGPR.)

We also offer a foster to adopt program.  You foster the dog, and have first right of refusal on them if an approved application is submitted for them.

Handsome, charming Isaac is a stealth operator - he'll steal your heart without you noticing! He's a 7 year old American Eskimo/terrier supermutt who arrived at ACL as a stray. He was very worried and unsure when he first arrived, and he didn't want to make friends. We knew it was an act, though, and soon found that he's a loyal, loving, tolerant dog who adores being with his people. He takes a little bit of patience to warm up to new people, but when you're in with Isaac, you're IN! His trust once earned is a permanent gift. Isaac isn't comfortable with other dogs, so he'd prefer to be a solo pet. He's a persnickety little terrier, so he'd do best with adopters 16 and up. Isaac's dream is to be the loyal companion to a quiet home who just wants a dog to go for short walks, have lots of pet time, and share their lives with. If Isaac could be the missing piece you've been looking for, please email Gabrielle at caninemanager@animalcareleague.org to schedule a meet!

Meet Nala!  Nala is a 6 month old female American Eskimo Dog. She is very sweet, but also very skittish. Nala is shy and afraid of new people and new situations. Nala was born on a country farm and lived in a barn until she was 5.5 months old. Nala needs a patient adopter who can spend time with her, socializing her and building her confidence. Nala will try to hide or run away when approached too fast, therefore she is a flight risk. Ideally, adopter should have time for socializing and formal training classes. A securely fenced yard is a huge plus. Eskie experience also a huge plus! If you are interested in adopting Nala, please send an email to:  CERApplications@gmail.com

Meet Foxy!  Foxy is a cute 12 month old female Mini Eskie. She is a cutie, but very suspicious of new people. Foxy needs time and patience to warm up, trust and accept new people; this does not happen in an hour, not over night, it takes several weeks for her to become comfortable. If approached too fast Foxy gets very scared and will bite to say back-off! Foxy has been spayed, fully vaccinated, heartworm negative, on Heartgard Plus, and microchipped. Foxy is being fostered in the Chicago suburbs, it is a requirement to be a local adopter so that the adopter can come visit Foxy a couple of times before trying to move her into their home. If you are interested in adopting Foxy, please send an email to: CERApplications@gmail.com

Meet Ned! Ned is now back on the adoption circuit, quite sadly due to the unexpected loss of his adoptive dad. He was really shaken up by this loss, so he has needed some extra understanding and love, but is now doing much better. Ned is a handsome Mini American Eskimo Dog, approx. 9+ in age and under 20 lbs, approx 18.5 lbs. Ned will prefer to have a quiet home, no children, and no active in-your-face dogs. Ned is generally an easy going boy, as long as things are going his way, as in not too chaotic! He likes to have a space to call his own, but he also loves to hang with his special person and get a good back rub! Ned has lost some of his vision (no meds needed) therefore it is imperative that no one sneaks up on him or tries to touch/grab him from the side or from behind. Ned can get pretty snarky and cranky if he doesn't know that you are coming up to him or if he is over tired from a hectic day. Also, this boy does not like slippery stairs, we feel that much of this is to do with his compromised eye sight as well as accidentally slipping on a wood or tile floor. With the proper carpeting or or even placing yoga mats down, he is much better. He will allow his person to carry him up and down stairs if needed, but a one level home would be ideal for him. Ned would be a perfect dog for someone who is recently retired and looking for a companion now. He is somewhat slow to warm up to new people, but once trust is earned, he is a buddy for life!

Ned is neutered, fully vaccinated, Heartworm negative, and microchipped. 

If you are interested in adopting Ned, please send an email to:  CERApplications@gmail.com

Foster Parents wanted! We have a challenge for you - To help us save the life of an American Eskimo Dog while we find a new home for this fur baby. Fostering is never easy but it is rewarding. The dog will be under your care for an average of a month. We provide all of the vetting costs. You provide love, stability, food and hugs. You will fall in love with each foster but will do so knowing that they will be adopted out to a great home and only because you opened your door for the second chance that they needed. Please join us for their sakes!  Interested? Please contact Paula at ChicagolandEskieRescue@live.com or 312-399-2056.

Chicagoland Eskie Rescue always has new American Eskimo Dogs coming into rescue. 70% of our dogs go to homes that have been preapproved through our application process. Please e-mail Paula at ChicagolandEskieRescue@live.com for an application so that we can preapprove you for that special new furbaby!

Chicagoland Eskie Rescue periodically has senior Eskies available for adoption! Don't pass up an older dog because of their age, often they are housebroken, calm, quiet, very cooperative, need limited exercise and make great companions. We try very hard to address any possible health issues prior to adoption, so there are no immediate surprises. All of our dogs adopt out with records of the vet care we have provided. All of our dogs will be spayed/neutered, vaccinated, microchipped, heartworm tested and prevention started, tested and/or wormed when needed, checked for fleas & flea/tick prevention started, fully groomed, and given a new collar and leash set with ID tag.
More PHOTOS SOON!
If you are interested in a senior Eskie please email to: Â chicagolandeskierescue@live.com
Thank you for considering a senior dog for adoption!Â
Betty White will be coming to Chicago soon! Details to follow!

Gorgeous special needs boy--funny boy!Hi! I'm Apollo! I am a one year old bully mix, and I weigh about 50 lbs. I'm housebroken and crate-trained. I loves to play with my peoples! I like other dogs after I get a slow and proper introduction to them. I haven't spent any time around cats, so I'm not sure how I feel about them. I am special needs--I'm deaf. Know what that means? You can vacuum, drop a heavy object, yell at the TV, and I'll just snore through it!'
I prefer older children, because I get excited when I play. I don't want to accidentally knock someone over or scare them with my energy! I love Nylabones and Kongs---and I love to destroy soft toys---so maybe I shouldn't have many of those ;-0. Hey---I'm young and I like to chew---I'll grow out of it, especially if I'm kept busy!

Trooper is an American Hairless Terrier as best we can tell. He has short hair on the upper body and peach fuzz on the underside. He is 11 months old, house trained, and will stay in a kennel when alone but not necessary. Currently weighing in at 11 pounds, he's a small guy with a big lovable personality.  He sleeps in the bed, under the covers. Daytime, he loves dog beds, which could be any container, box, pillow or blanket that he can fit in. Trooper's favorite pass time is collecting toys, socks, clothes,etc. He brings them out into the living room so he can keep an eye on all his toys. Trooper stays close and doesnât wander or run off once he is attached to you. He is good on a leash and loves to be outside in warm weather. He will ask to go out, do his business, and comes back in. Trooper is not used with small children but should be fine with teenagers. He is a shy boy around strangers and new animals, but does love to play once he gets to know them- not aggressive, just avoids contact. Trooper barks only when people enter the house, he takes his role as a watchdog seriously and sounds the alarm. He is otherwise not a barker. Trooper is skittish in crowds, and loves car rides. He is energetic without being crazy and loves to play tug of war and fetch the ball. He is very eager to please but will get performance anxiety if pressed too hard or too harshly scolded, which occasionally will  show as a submissive wet if he is unsure what you want from him because he wants so badly to please. He does extremely well with positive verbal reward.  Trooper is a great companion dog and needs interaction and action because he is so smart. While playful, he also loves to snuggle.  Lap dog half the time, devoted, funny, very intelligent, learns quickly. He has never been with cats.   He is 'aggressively submissive' with other dogs he knows.  He will take play bites on the snout and head but will not back up if he wants their attention or the toy they have. (not with people though) A home where he can be solo dog, or with an easy going playful canine companion is ideal. Trooper will be a one in a million dog if you know how to work with him! Please email cheryl.hwb1@gmail.com with questions.

Echo Glen Children's Center is a youth correctional facility located approximately 30 minutes east of Seattle. Meet the dog with the most ridiculous name ever: Maraschino! She is a 4 yr. old, 45 lb, Pittie mix that we evacuated from a shelter in the path of Irma several months ago. She had obviously been someone's beloved pet because she had her own pink camo collar and pink painted toenails. She broke our hearts and there was no way we could leave her behind!

She is great with other dogs, and very easy-going. She loves to play, and when she meets new dogs her tail wags so fast it's a blur! She loves wrestling, and playing chase, and playing fetch (either with you or all by herself).

She has been great with all of the people (and kids) she has met, happy and affectionate. This girl has never met a stranger and wants to be everyone's best friend! She loves butt scratches and will happily show off her twerking skills in exchange for a good scratch. This girl is a typical happy-go-lucky Pittie, and is as sweet as her name!

She's not so great with cats however, so this is a no-cats kinda girl! 

She is medium to high energy and does best with a few long walks or play sessions per day, and then is perfectly content to cuddle. She will even wait for you to come tuck her in under a blank for her naps. She still pulls when on leash, although her foster family is working on this with her.

She already knows her basic commands, is trustworthy in the house, is crate trained and potty trained. This girl is seriously perfect and deserves her new forever home!

If you have an open spot on your couch and think Maraschino would be a fun name to call outside in your robe and slippers, please go to our website and fill out an adoption application (link below)! 

If you are interested in adopting this dog, please FIRST apply online, at https://bigfluffydogs.com/adopt/adoption-application/
Our Website www.bigfluffydogs.com has more information about us and the adoption process. If you still have questions, you can reach out to corey@bigfluffydogs.com.

NOTE TO EMAILERS FROM PETFINDER: WE DO NOT ALWAYS RESPOND TO EMAIL INQUIRIES WITHOUT AN APPLICATION DUE TO THE SHEER NUMBER WE GET DAILY. WE REGRET WE CANNOT RESPOND TO EVERY EMAIL, BUT UNLESS YOU FILL OUT AN APPLICATION, WE MIGHT NOT KNOW YOU EXIST. 

* BEHAVIOR DISCLAIMER: We do our best to provide accurate information, but adopters must understand that each home is different and the dog may behave differently in a new home. Dogs are creatures of their environment and you help make the dog what it will be. All dogs will require supervision with children, other dogs, and cats/other animals regardless of whether or not we have stated that the dog is friendly towards kids, cats, other dogs, etc. Slow introductions to other animals in the home, and allowing for them to have a separate space will make for better relationships in the future. Most dogs need an adjustment period when transitioning into a new home and there may be potty accidents, even if we have stated the dog is housebroken. All dogs should be somehow confined separately (crate or separate room) when left home alone until you can be sure the dog is trustworthy left loose. Separation anxiety can manifest if a dog is left alone more than it is used to in it's new home. This can be worked through and we are here to help. Please do not give up on your new dog without reaching out to us first!

Arrival Story: Waggin' Tails found Gizmo at Detroit Animal Care and Control.  After meeting and playing with Gizmo, we knew we had to help this happy dog find a great new family.

Approximate Age/Weight: 3 years / 50 lbs.

Personality:  Gizmo is a silly, playful little bundle of brindle happiness.  We met him at the shelter where he won over one of our volunteers during a play session.  Gizmo has a gentle mouth and takes treats gently and drops toys easily.  He loves toys, eating meals out of Kongs and chewing on bully sticks. He does act puppyish and still sometimes mouths hands when playing (no biting, just mouthing) so we're working on that.  He graduated from Training Buddies, Mind Your Manners class.  

Gizmo has had a DNA test and we discovered that he is 78.5% American Staffordshire Terrier with 12.% of mixed breed identifiable as only parts of the sporting, hound, and mountain dog groups.   Gizmo is a svelt 50lbs full grown.

Gizmo has good house manners and hasn't played with anything other than his toys in the house.  He took to crate training easily. 
 
Gizmo is a fun dog who really enjoys time with people, is making good eye contact and checking in with his handler on walks. He is a leaner, and will curl into you for some pets or sit on your lap for snuggle time.  He would love to sleep with you and provide warmth on cold nights.  Giz is great at morning snuggles!   Our boy is adventurous and likes to explore and follows his nose wherever it goes. He wears a harness on walks. Gizmo is good on car rides but needs to be secured or heâll be trying to drive.   Gizmo is treat-motivated and wants to learn and is super smart.  He is more busy-body than couch potato and likes to know what is going on the house so he is happy to tag along when you do chores.  He is not much of a barker and likes to sit at the front window and watch the neighborhood goings on.  Gizmo doesn't bark at people or dogs passing by.
 
Forever Home: Gizmo could fit into many different home situations.  He would likely knock over a little one with his bouncy, happy-go-lucky nature so older kids would be best.  He is young and still needs a good amount of playtime.

Contact: Please contact wtdr2008@yahoo.com if interested in adopting Gizmo!

If you are interested adopting a dog, please download an Adoption Application from our website,www.waggintailsdogrescue.org/adoptionprocess.html and email it to wtdr2008@yahoo.com.
 
ADOPTION INFO:
 
We do not have a facility; all of our dogs are fostered in private homes.   We generally have two adoption events per month.  To meet a dog in person, please see our event calendar on our website for the date and time of the next adoption event. Arrangements can be made to meet a dog outside of Saturday adoption events after an application is submitted and approved.

Our adoption process includes an application and in-home meet-n-greet with the dog.
   
-Adult Dog Adoption Fee - $225
-Small Breed Adoption Fee - $275
-Senior Dog Adoption Fee - $125
-Pup Adoption Fee - $250 plus $50 spay/neuter deposit refunded upon proof of surgery by 6 mos.

Click here to watch a video of Hailey.Last Day Dog Rescue now microchips all animals before adoption. Microchips are implanted between the animals shoulder blades and are a permanent form of identification. The microchips are registered to Last Day Dog Rescue with the adopter's info added once adopted. If the animal is ever lost and slips his/her collar/tags the microchip allows the finder to know who to contact if scanned for a microchip. Animals MUST still have a collar with tags on at all times. Per our contract, we take all our animals back if for any reason you can't keep your adopted animal.

The Petfinder.com system requires that we choose a predominant breed or breed mix for our animals. Visual breed identification in animals is unreliable so for most of the animals we are only guessing at predominant breed or breed mix. We get to know each animal as an individual and will do our best to describe each of our animals based on personality, not by breed label.

Thank you for looking through our list of animals needing forever homes and choosing rescue first. We appreciate you stopping by.

Because he is so big, and has a tendency to want to rough house, we recommend kids 10 and up.  If you are looking for a boy who wants to play, this is your guy!

In Greek mythology, Atlas was a Titan condemned to hold up the sky for eternity after the Titanomachy.   For travelers, an atlas was first generation roadmap.  If you're a new car buyer you may be considering the Volkswagen Atlas minivan.  For Big Fluffy Dog lovers, Atlas is a 2.5 year old Anatolian/GSD cross. That's the one we'll talk about today.  

Atlas is basically a giant puppy.  Although we have no doubt that he'll be able to bear the weight of the world on his shoulders (this guy will be 100+ pounds), we're not sure he wouldn't try to toss it up in the air and catch it, too.  Atlas has the high prey drive and energy common to GSDs.  Atlas may be best suited to a home with any other dogs.  If you are a  cat free home with older, sturdy (remember, he's 100+ pounds of puppy) children and think this guy is for you, please email audrey@bigfluffydogs.com after you fill out the adoption application at https://bigfluffydogs.com/adopt/adoption-application/

Furever Tails is a non-profit, no-kill, foster home based animal rescue based out of Oakland Township, MI. Our foster animals are living in our foster homes and treated like family until they find their own furever family. Our adoption process requires an application to be completed and approved before a meet-n-greet with the animal can take place. Adoption fees are necessary to help us cover vetting costs for our rescued animals.

Blanche is a 5-year old, Anatolian Shepherd mix that weighs in just around 50 pounds. She is strong, beautiful, and full of confidence.  True to her breed, she is always the observer.  She takes her job seriously of monitoring and making sure all is well; however, she does not bark unless there is a serious threat.  She is very loyal, super smart, and an independent thinker, exactly what youâd expect from her breed.
She is great with other dogs and older kids.  No cats, squirrels, or rabbits for this girl.  She is good on a leash and LOVES car rides!  She takes treats like a lady and she loves to play with toys and bones, but her very favorite pastime is to snuggle.  If you let her, she will sleep with you.  She is totally house trained and can be trusted to be left out while you are out of the house.  Only adopters with physical fences or a commitment to leash walking need apply.

If you are interested in adopting this dog, please apply online, at http: https://bigfluffydogs.com/adopt/adoption-application/ then email Audrey@BigFluffyDogs.com.

 Our main website, www.bigfluffydogs.com has more information about us and the rescue process. NOTE TO EMAILERS FROM PETFINDER: WE DO NOT RESPOND TO EMAIL INQUIRIES WITHOUT AN APPLICATION. WE REGRET WE CANNOT RESPOND TO EVERY EMAIL, BUT UNLESS YOU FILL OUT AN APPLICATION, WE DO NOT KNOW YOU EXIST. All known information about an individual dog is provided in it's listing. We do our best to provide accurate information, but adopters must understand that each home is different and the dog may behave differently in a new home. Dogs are creatures of their environment and you help make the dog what it will be. 

Homes considering adopting a puppy must be prepared for: 1.) Flexible schedules for potty training. Puppies can only hold it for one hour per month of age (ex. a 4 month old puppy can only go 4 hours without a potty break). 2.) Crate training until the puppy is at least one year old, to prevent chewing on inappropriate things when you can't supervise. 3.) Socialization: The more positive and varying experiences as a puppy the better, both in and out of your home. 4.) Puppy behavior and life stages are equivalent to a human toddler. It takes at least a full year to have a calmer, well-adjusted dog. Patience is required and when your dog's behavior is a positive experience for you and those around you, your patience will be rewarded tenfold, for years to come. Please do not consider adopting a puppy if you have not thoroughly thought through the pros and cons of having one. So many people end up returning them after 3-5 months because they didn't realize the amount of work involved in raising a puppy. Patience, appropriate toys, socialization, and obedience training are all musts. All are time consuming, and can be expensive. All Dogs Require: Supervision with children and obedience training. Adopters that want to have good dogs must be prepared to put the time and effort into training a dog. Any dog requires work and effort, but a well-trained, well-socialized dog is more than worth the effort put in to get them there.

Bold Ruler came to us from a kill shelter in Alabama where he ended up by no fault of his own. He can be a little timid at first, but is good with people & other dogs. His approx. birth date is 01/01/15 and he currently weighs 70#. UPDATE - THIS KID HAS SOME VERY STRONG GUARDING SKILLS IN HIS HOME. He needs a strong handler or someone with herding breed experience and a structured household. 
He has been vet. checked, neutered, micro chipped, heart worm tested negative, is up to date on routine shots & wormings including rabies and has been treated with flea & heart worm preventative per our protocol. 
His adoption donation is $250 and needs to be cash, cashier's check or money order. We do not ship or transport. 
Please email for an application if you would like to provide this handsome lad with his forever home.

Margo Markle is an american pup looking for her prince (or princess). All Margo  wants is to sit on the throne one day as QUEEN and enjoy her privacy (without peasants) with her person.  To rule over her castle and be your one and only is her dream.  Margo Markle  is an ANATOLIAN SHEPHERD Dog who bonds with her person. She would love to find a person that is home with her  often (or maybe even works from home) and she is happiest when you are around. Margo does require slow intros to new people (she is special and require lots of patience and structure from her adoptive family) as she can be aloof to others.

Note: We will be adopting Margo only to a family local in Columbus, Oh. 

Margo's adoption fee is $230. She is spayed, UTD on vaccines, micro-chipped, heartworm negative and on heartworm/flea/tick prevention.

Fallon is such a beautiful girl!!!!! She is strikingly good looking and gets complements all the time but she doesn't let it go to her head!  She's a tomboy who likes to rough & tumble and chase more than anything; playing with other dogs is definitely her favorite thing to do.  When we got her, she'd been abused so was timid with new people, especially men.  But she's blossomed into a happy, well-adjusted girl who enjoys attention and getting her ears scratched. She's active so would be a great running partner but would be equally happy racing around the back yard after toys.  Her favored playmates are males ... she's not a "girly-girl" but she is fine with females; she just doesn't really romp with them.  Because of her anatolian heritage, she instinctively is protective of her people and property.  When her foster mom is around, she's very social and friendly with visitors.  But if strangers appear and mom's not home, Fallon is definitely stand-offish.  She's extremely loyal and very eager to please so would excel in obedience training,  She appears to be potty trained and, although she loves toys (especially the squeaky ones!), she is not destructive with them.  She is protective of her food with other dogs (but not with people) so isn't recommended in a home with children under 10 years old.

Gypsy is a WONDERFUL dog! How is this for a good testimonial... Gypsy's foster mom has 4 dogs and has fostered over 50 (I know, she is pretty amazing!) and  she has said that Gypsy is the easiest foster she has ever had!!  Gypsy is beautiful with a soft coat that is perfect for cuddling up to on a cold winter night!  She is playful but easily calms down to relax and cuddle.  She is big but not a giant. She loves other dogs and and played very well with all the dogs she has met.  She had FHO surgery and has healed very well.  We believe that is at least partly due to the natural therapy she gets running and playing with her canine foster siblings. Because she loves playing with other dogs and also because playing with them is great therapy for her leg, Gypsy must go to a home with a fenced yard and another dog who wants a playful, friendly sister.   She has met kids and was gentle and well behaved with them, too.  She is quite a prize and she is ready to make a family think they just won the doggy adoption lottery.  

The process to adopt starts with the potential adopter filling out the application form at our website http://www.safenowrescue.com . Your application will be reviewed and someone should email or call within a day or two to let you know your application has been received and it is being reviewed (or forwarded if the pet is in a foster home). If you do not hear back within 2 days please call in case there was a problem. It is possible the dog youâve applied for has an application before you or an adoption pending; we will let you know if that is the case. Once your application is approved you should hear back from someone within a couple of days. If all goes well and the dog or puppy is still available and it appears it will be a good fit for your home and family, you would then make an appointment for yourself and your family members to meet the dog. most often a home visit will be required. From application to adoption it could take anywhere from 2 days to 2 weeks  (depending on schedules and if the dog/puppy still needs to have medical work done).

The adoption fee is $325.00 and includes deworming, vaccinations, microchip and being spayed..  


**Please note we are NOT positive of breeds.  The dogs usually come from shelters and often little is known about their background so we make a best guess on the breed when we advertise for adoption.

She loves toys and will bring them over to you just to show you.  She loves food and will settle down with a nice chew.  Thelma is about 7 years old and weighs just under 70 pounds.  She is very sweet and would do best as an only dog in a home and with children 12 or older.

I would recommend if you havenât done so already that you submit a general online adoption application with us so it is on file for when you are ready to come out and adopt.  The adoption counselors will be able to show you many  that would be a good fit for your family.  We do go in order of when you submitted your application with us.  So it is always best that you get your general application for any animal in with us as soon as possible.
Here is the link to the Adoption Application: https://www.animalhouseshelter.com/adoption-application/

We are a foster based rescue based out of Muskegon, MI. We have an application process for adopting our pets. We have an application on our website www.caninesrescue.com. Johnny is a very sweet boy who loves to play ball! He was brought here from Texas shortly after Hurricane Harvey along with his sister Alice. He's doing very well with potty training and crate training. He seems to get along well with dogs of any size. Johnny is so easy going and laid back!

My name is Miss Diamond and I'm a very sweet girl. I love to run and play and give hugs. I like to get kisses and hugs too. I like belly rubs and playing with toys. I'm a working dog and I would love to learn a job. I was on a chain most of my life until I was rescued. I'm very smart and energetic. Please send your phone number to find out more about me.

George was born on 12/3/2012 and weighs about 44 pounds.  He was originally adopted from Homeward Bound as a pup and since then his family situation has changed and they are no longer able to spend the time with George that George needs.  He is very smart, loves to play and cuddle, house and crate trained and good on leash. He is good with other dogs, only children 14 and above and he does not like cats. He does not like the water (ie lakes, pools).   George needs a home where someone will be home more than gone, able to give him the attention, time and exercise he needs, no small children.  He will make a nice addition to the right family.

If you are interested in adopting me, please copy and paste the following "online application" into a new email to homewardboundmi@yahoo.com and then simply answer the questions. PLEASE MAKE SURE THE PET'S NAME IS IN THE EMAIL 'SUBJECT LINE'.

Our adoption radius is within 60 miles of Canton, MI as home visits are required for our pets prior to placing them in their new forever homes.

NOTE: Please be patient with us once you've sent this preliminary application. We get several applications and it may take a few days before we are able to review it. We will keep your application in the order it is received and if you are selected or the next applicant on the list we will contact you. 

FOLLOWING IS THE ONLINE APPLICATION---All questions must be answered COMPLETELY and you MUST be 21 years of age to be considered for one of our rescues:

Please provide your full name: 
Please provide your home address including the city and State and what the closest crossroads are?
What County do you live in?
How long have you lived at this address?   
How many times have you moved in the past 5 years?
Any plans on moving within the next 6 months?  If yes, why and where?
Please include a phone number that we may be able to contact you either during the day or evening and when it would be best to contact you. 
Place of employment and phone number?
Driver License #, State and Expiration Date
How many adults in the household and what are their ages?  
Do you have children? if so, how many and their ages?
Does anyone in the household have allergies?
Will this pet be a family pet, companion pet, childâs pet, gift, company for another pet or other (explain)? 
Do you have a fenced in yard? if so, what type - privacy, cyclone, etc. 
Is your fence secure enough for the pet you are applying for? 
Do you have a detached garage? 
Do you have a doggie door?  
If you do not have a fence, how will you let the animal outside?   
Do you own or rent your residence?   
Is your residence a house, condo, mobile home, etc?  
If you rent, are pets allowed at your location?  
Have you ever owned a dog/cat or a puppy/kitten before?  
If so, what kind, do you still have them and if you don't, what specifically happened to them and when?  
What is or were their name, breed and age?
If you have been a pet owner before, please list your veterinarian(s) name and phone number(s)?
If you have been a pet owner before, was your pet spayed or neutered, up to date on its shots and on
heartworm preventative?
If you are selected where (specifically) will this animal be kept during the day and where will it sleep at night?
While at work how long will the animal be left home alone?
If housebreaking is needed, how will you do this?
Will you crate train? 
Do you know how to crate train?
If so, will you continue to use a crate?
Will you take this canine to an obedience class?
Who specifically will be responsible for the care, exercising and feeding of this new pet?
What would you do with this pet if you need to move?
What would you do with this pet if you could no longer take care of it for any reason?
Have you ever owned a pet that you had to place elsewhere? If so, who did you give the pet to and for what reason?
Have you ever applied for one of our pets before?   If so when and what was the petâs name?

All STAR animals come vetted, Up to Date (UTD) on age appropriate shots and testing, spay and neutered (if of age,) and microchipped.

AGE DISCLAIMER:
Unfortunately, most of the orphaned animals that come into our rescue looking for homes donât bring birth certificates. Sometimes we know our petsâ ages. Sometimes we donât. So we make our best guess based on the condition of their teeth and the veterinarians best guess.
BREED DISCLAIMER:
Visual breed identification in dogs is unreliable so for most of the dogs we are only guessing at predominant breed or breed mix. We get to know each dog as an individual and will do our best to describe each of our dogs based on personality,
not
by breed label .
Microchips:
For the safety of our dogs and peace of mind of our fosters and adopters, STAR microchips all dogs prior to adoption with Petlink Microchips. Please understand that all dogs MUST still wear a collar with ID tags (which include your current information) AT ALL TIMES. Please remember, our foster dogs are extremely important to us-- we will always take any of our dogs back, if for any reason you can't keep your adopted dog. Never surrender him/her to a shelter!

Ramona is new to the rescue so we are still getting to know her. She is a very sweet girl and has been very well behaved for her foster family - including walking well on a leash, being quiet in her crate, and not being destructive. Ramona likes to play with her foster brother and she is house broken. She was surrendered to a pound for killing chickens, so we do not think she should live with cats or other small animals. We will share more info about her as we get to know her better!

Last Day Dog Rescue now microchips all animals before adoption. Microchips are implanted between the animals shoulder blades and are a permanent form of identification. The microchips are registered to Last Day Dog Rescue with the adopter's info added once adopted. If the animal is ever lost and slips his/her collar/tags the microchip allows the finder to know who to contact if scanned for a microchip. Animals MUST still have a collar with tags on at all times. Per our contract, we take all our animals back if for any reason you can't keep your adopted animal.

The Petfinder.com system requires that we choose a predominant breed or breed mix for our animals. Visual breed identification in animals is unreliable so for most of the animals we are only guessing at predominant breed or breed mix. We get to know each animal as an individual and will do our best to describe each of our animals based on personality, not by breed label.

Thank you for looking through our list of animals needing forever homes and choosing rescue first. We appreciate you stopping by.

Babe Ruth is an adorable puppy!  SHe is around 10 weeks old and a very sweet little girl .  SHe is up to date on vaccines and her adoption fee is $350 with $50 refunded or donated back to Good Karma when you get her spayed

Please do not send inquiries asking if animals are still available, if you see it online, that means it is.  We only post available animals.  In order to adopt one of our puppies or dogs, an application must be filled out prior to attending an adoption event.  If approved, you will be invited to attend the adoption event.  

We hold adoption events every Sunday, unless otherwise noted, at Premier Pet Supply, 31215 Southfield Rd,  Beverly Hills, MI, from 1-4 pm.

Please note that these animals in most cases are abandoned and therefore breeds and sizes are our best estimates based on years of experience.  Many times we do not know the parents, so we are guessing.  If you are looking for a specific breed or size maybe rescue is not for you, it is very possible you will adopt a puppy we say will be medium size and the pup may be smaller than estimated or may be larger than estimated.  We do our best but many times we are wrong so please beware of this before rescuing from us.

Bella and her seven puppies were surrendered to us after she gave birth in a garage  She is very happy her 7 puppies got wonderful homes.  It is now time to get Bella a home of her own.
She has been with HomeFurever for about a year and a half.  She gets looked over week after week. She would make a great companion if someone would give her a chance.
 Bella is super affectionate and has a playful side as well.
She will cuddle in bed with you and give lots of kisses.  She will definitely steal your hear
She gets along with smaller dogs and larger dogs if properly introduced.
She should be placed in a home with children 10 and up. 
She would prefer a home with no cats as she likes to chase them.
She would also be perfectly fine as an only dog as she does like all of the attention.
Bella is very attached to her foster mom and her 10 year old daughter.
She  will need time and patience to get adjusted to her new home.
Bella weighs 45 pounds and walks good on a leash.
Please open your home and heart to this sweetheart. Birth date 2/24/12

Home FurEver is a non-profit foster based canine rescue seeking foster parents, volunteers and donations. Please see our website for more information.
 
Please note that Home FurEver does not post applications on line. We will receive all applications in person at local adoption events in order to conduct an in-person interview.  All members of the household should be present for the application and interview process. All applicants require a home inspection and vet check - Please note that we cannot drive more than an hour to do a home inspection.  We do require a fenced back yard for all bully breeds.  Some dogs may require households with children over a certain age.
 
Ask yourself some questions before you consider bringing a new dog home.   1.  Am I ready for a LIFE LONG commitment?  2. Am I prepared for a roudy puppy?  3. Am I prepared to potty train?   4. Is this the right breed for me or my family?  5. Can I afford the food and vet care for this dog?  6. Is it best to have a totally fenced yard?  7. Will I make a commitment to obedience training?

Hello! I am Spice Girl, a 2-3 year old mixed breed girl. I have a beautiful red coat with freckles and adorable ears. I am such a happy, enthusiastic girl with a love for life. I am playful and love toys but I also know how to chill out and relax in the house during down time. I like to play fetch and am learning to catch frisbees too! I am crate trained and house trained in my foster home. I have been around lots of different dogs and have done well with them but I may be too interested for very small dogs or cats. I mostly am interested in my people and hanging out with them. I have also enjoyed attention and play from respectful children. I will be a wonderful addition to a wide variety of families looking for a new family member. Could that be you?

We do not have a facility for you to visit.

WE PROCESS APPLICANTS AND SET APPOINTMENTS BASED ON THE ORDER APPLICATIONS ARE RECEIVED

, so while you are welcome to call (248) 834-9419 or email
ccrcdogs@ccrcdogs.com
with specific questions, you will want to complete the

ONLINE APPLICATION

ASAP
,

which can be found at www.ccrcdogs.com,

to secure your position in line for one of our dogs. You can also find

a description of our process on that same page. Puppies will not be available to be seen until their 10 day quarantine has passed. Our adoption fee is $200 for adults and $275 for puppies, which covers the cost of the spay/neuter, age appropriate shots and tests, medications to bring the dog to full health, and a free visit with one of our approved vets after adoption. The majority of dogs at CCRC are obtained from animal control centers, so there is often very little known about their history or even current habits. You can always expect to do some training, regardless of whether you adopt a dog or a puppy, including crate training, house training, and basic manners. CCRC provides a variety of materials and resources to assist you with this, as well as telephone support.

Our adoption fees include the pets spay or neuter, microchip, up to date vaccines, heartworm/tick disease testing and fecal check.  All adoption fees can be found on our groups' Petfinder page.  The first step to our adoption process is to fill out an adoption application on our website,  www.serenityanimalhospital.net, under the "Adopt From Us" Tab. Please email the application to adoptions@serenityanimalhospital.net or drop it off in person during our business hours. This is sweet Mona, originally she was Kona.  Mona has a heartbreaking story. 

She came in as a 10 month old owner turn in.  She was VERY high energy and the shelter didn't want to try and place her.  I was able to get her out of the shelter and Jen who was a runner, was very excited to find a young dog who had the energy to run with her daily.  

Jen and Mona became very tightly bonded as a pet parent and her little girl.   Last year Jen was in a very high speed car accident, she was run off the road coming home from work and went under a semi.  Jen broke her ankle and her back. Mona was devasted seeing Jen coming home from the hospital and she didn't leave her side. 


Jen and Mona had to move home to Jen's parents home, losing her job, her apartment and was bed bound for nearly a year.  Mona needs to be run daily, she has a lot of energy and Jen was having her parents exercise Mona hoping she would soon recover.  

Mona was by Jen's side constantly and became her nurse maid.  After two failed surgeries to repair Jen's spine and ankle, recently came the news Jen was not expecting to hear.  Only 25 years old, Jen will not be recovering any time soon if at all.  The surgeons can't seem to get her surgeries to heal her ankle and her spine might need more time than they had projected.  Without Mona Jen wasn't sure she could pull through, but now it's been more than a year and Mona is getting very impatient with the slow recovery and Jen's parents can not exercise Mona enough to keep her happy.   

Jen has decided it could be years IF she does recover.  Devasted she has decided it's best for her little girl to go to a pet parent who can continue her daily runs, without that outlet Mona gets anxious and can get out of hand.  With the exercise she's a angel.  

We are looking for a non smoking home with a VERY active runner or hiker who can be home with her, or working from home.   She needs property to live on and she is NOT good with other animals but is good with older children. 

  She is VERY faithful to her person and she'd do great with agility or having a job to focus on.  She's good with people, adults, and she's somewhat of a rare dog.  She's a Kelpie mix, about 45 pounds, tons of energy. This website didn't even have Kelpie as a breed you could choose to list him.

 Kelpies are working dogs, so those kinds of herding dogs need a job to do or they get bored.  She's three years old, loves car rides, and she's cute as a button.   She's housebroken loves being a inside pup, but LOVES long walks through the woods or runs on trails.  She could be exercised by jogging along a bicycle or keeping her pet parent in shape.   

If you think you would love a faithful rare breed pup who will be your best constant companion, please call or text me at 517 294 4514.  Or email me at marlas2468@yahoo.com   Jen will be extremely sad to lose Mona, she has been dealing with this decision for nearly a year now and she's come to grips with the fact that sometimes, if you love someone enough, you have to do what is best for them.  Mona has waited a long year for Jen to recover and it's been very tough on her to sit by and watch Jen lay in bed.  Jen says she never has loved anyone as much as she does Mona, that Mona is her best friend ever.   Mona desparately needs a person or couple or family with young adults to become her new family and enjoy her, she's had a tough go of things.

Both of these girls are very affectionate and truly enjoy time being petted and cuddled.  They are also energetic and playful!  They would do well with children over the age of 5, as well as with dog-friendly feline siblings.  So if you're looking for double the love, look no further than Nubi and Izzy!

Molly was rescued in February friom a slaughterhouse in Changchun, China. After quarantine she came to the US in September. Molly has had a tough life and apparently a few puppies along the way. There is a sadness about Molly, but she is learning to enjoy being petted and loved on and would do well in a quiet adult home. She can be a little growly with other dogs and especially with food...but she has had to stick up for herself in the nightmare life she came from. She loves the security of a crate and appears to be housebroken. She does very well on a leash and likes walks. She is learning trust in this new environment. She was partially shaved when she arrived and her coat is beginning to come in. Because of her sad past, we want a stable, patient and dedicated home where she will be loved and cherished. She is an ambassador for the many victims of the cruel dog meat trade and we would like to see her continuing to educate people about the dogs who were not so lucky.

Mollyâs adoption fee is $275 and includes her spay, microchip, vaccinations and heartworm test. She even has her own puppy passport! For an online application go to blackdogsrescue.org/adoptions. For more info email blackdogs@me.com.

Harley is a 5 year old, 45 pound Kelpie. She came to Iowa from Texas after Hurricane Harvey.  Harley was homeless before the hurricane and moved north to make room for the dogs that would need to be held so their owners could find them after the storm.   

Harley needed some help when she arrived in Iowa. She had a small limbal tumor in her left eye and had eye surgery to remove it. Harley also had a painful neck. The vets discovered she had a herniated disc in her neck and did another surgery to fix it. Harley is now happy and healthy and ready to find a home of her own.   

Harley is a sweet, gentle girl who loves attention. She has great house manners. Harley has two favorite things in life. Car rides and soft toys. Harley will happily hop in a car and go anywhere with you. She rides shotgun and does great. Harley carries her soft toys everywhere with her and loves to cuddle with them.  

Since Harley is a Kelpie, she is one of the smartest of all breeds. She is highly intelligent and learns quickly. Her superior intellect combined with her intensity and passion for keeping busy means she needs an owner smarter than she is.    

Harleyâs forever home should have a fenced yard and no kids under 10. Kelpieâs were bred to herd and she would quickly have small children herded up. Harley would be happiest to be an only dog but would also do well with a calm male dog. A cat would be viewed as a squeaky toy.   

Harley is spayed, up to date on vaccinations, microchipped and heartworm tested.

Indoor homes only.?

Meet FAPPY....she is Fat & Happy...this she is our wonderful FAPPY....this girl keeps us smiling constantly. This cutie may seem nervous at 1st, but give her just a little time and she is wide open! Kristin (A225695) LOVES attention and to play. Squeaky noises (and toys) really catch her interest! Due to her energy level and how she is a little nervous at 1st we would not recommend her for small children. We think once in a home Kristin will be such a wonderful and loyal companion. We think that Kristin is an Australian Kelpie mix, which is a herding breed. These breeds are known for their smarts and their will to work. If not given the outlet they need they can be destructive. Due to being herding breeds, it is also common that is Kristin doesn't have things to herd she will find things to herd... such as other pets or even your children. At 10 months old this girl is at a great training age! She is also full grown at 36 lbs. Kristin is scheduled to be spayed and microchipped April 10, 2018. She is now current on vaccines and is heartworm negative!

Biscuit is a SPAZ!  

That being said, he is also a sweetheart.  He has his really smart moments, then his ADHD moments.  Biscuit is 90% house trained and crate trained. He showed up at neighboring properties and they called me to pick him up since he wanted to go in their homes and be their best friend...LOL

Biscuit is being fostered in Scottsville, VA

Meet Angel! Angel is a 37 lb Shepherd, Kelpie mix with an astounding personality. She loves napping and cuddle time of course, but also enjoys fishing and playing around with the other dogs in her foster home. She would be good in a home with an active family who go to the park, long walks or likes hiking. 
Angel, who is only 18 months old, was found walking the streets of Memphis, so we believe she came from a rough background and was probably abandoned. Because of this neglect she needs and craves attention, but overall she loves to please and is dying to do so. She is house trained and we're working with her on basic commands like sit, stay and lay down. She is also crate trained but because she is so good in the house she rarely spends time in the crate!

Angel was named Angel because her foster mom says she is the kindest, most angelic soul has ever encountered. The only thing Angel doesn't seem to enjoy is baths! Everything else brings so much joy and happiness to her. This beautiful little girl wants a family who she can please, run around with, and lay on the couch with. She is spayed, microchipped, up to date on all her shots, and ready for her home. If you want to make Angel a part of your family, please apply at peace4paws.org.

Beauty is an adorable 10-year-old Shepherd x Kelpie mix.   She is vetted and ready for adoption.

 She may have a stub for a tail but that doesn't keep her from wagging it!  She will curl up on the couch or in the chair beside me.  She sleeps in bed with her foster mom but would probably be happy on a dog bed next to your bed.  She loves to be pet and will stand by your chair while you rub her back.

In her foster home, she gets along fine with a 16-year-old Golden mix (who wouldn't?) and most of the time with another 16-month-old foster dog, Shepherd mix, Beau.  She will get a little possessive towards Beau when she's sitting near me and he comes for attention.  She can be aggressive at the dog park so tread carefully there.

She would do best with a fenced in yard because she rarely will do her business if she's on a lead or leash.  She rides well in a car but does like to chat about what she sees.  In my car she is egged on by Beau so she would probably be quiet if no one else is yapping!

She's a love bug with a sweet face and Yoda ears!

Her adoption fee is $100.00.  We require our dogs to be inside dogs, we will not allow them to be tied or tethered.  This dog requires a 6' high fenced yard.  If you are interested in applying for her, you can complete an application at https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe4gffGMpNVa3DTWnrzl6Z_fSP3E4nICkWcURjQPC2B0Upveg/viewform

Crate Trained: Yes
Walks Nicely on a leash:  Yes 
Knows Basic Commands:  This smart guy knows the basics - sit, shake, give
Energy Level: Medium-High

Special Needs: Since Earl has allergies, he will need to stay on medicine year-round.  He is on two meds that will cost approx $100 per month.  
 
Arrival Story: Earl came to Waggin Tails after his previous owners were unable to take care of him.  He has allergies that had gotten out of control and this poor guy was pretty miserable.  Waggin Tails has been able to find some medication that controls Earlâs itching.  He is very nervous at the vetâs office, but weâve found a great vet who gently works with Earl to ease his fears using fear-free methods. 
 
Approximate Age/Weight: 7-8 years / 72 lbs.
 
Personality:  Earl is a super smart and sweet dog.  He makes his foster parents laugh every day with his antics!  He was a superstar in his training class and graduated with flying colors!    

Earl LOVES to play fetch!  Tennis balls or other dog toys, it doesnât matter.  He will bring the ball back to you or set it down near you non-stop.  He will also point at it so you know exactly what he wants.    When playtime is over, Earl does settle down nicely for naps - even if the tennis ball is still in his mouth!  

This smart guy loves to go for walks and has learned to walk nicely on leash.  Good boy, Early Bird!

Earl likes to cuddle up and get belly rubs.   He has great house manners, too!

He would make a great agility, free-style dance or possible dock diving dog - he would do really well with some kind of job or sport.  He is wicked smart and food motivated, so heâs very easily trained and would rise to the challenge.  He really enjoys learning new tricks!

There are three other dogs in his foster home and Earl gets along with all of them.  He doesnât try to engage in play with them, but heâs also not opposed to settling down next to one of the other dogs and chewing on a Nylabone.  He has shown no interest in the resident cat, but is interested in squirrels and birds in the back yard.
 
Forever Home: We would love to see Earl go to a home with some dog experience and a fenced in yard so that he can run after tennis balls/toys safely.  After all that heâs been through, handsome Earl needs to be with someone who is willing to give him the attention and playtime that he deserves.  While Earl behaves nicely around children, a home without young children is ideal.  If you're looking for a super fun and funny guy, he may be the one for you!


Contact:  Please contact wtdr2008@yahoo.com if you're interested in adopting Earl.     .

Ask yourself some questions before you consider bringing a new dog home.   1.  Am I ready for a LIFE LONG commitment?  2. Am I prepared for a rowdy puppy?  3. Am I prepared to potty train?   4. Is this the right breed for me or my family?  5. Can I afford the food and vet care for this dog?  6. Is it best to have a totally fenced yard?  7. Will I make a commitment to obedience training?

This handsome fellow was picked up beside a highway in southern Ohio on 5/20/10.  There were no houses for a couple of miles in either direction, and he wasn't wearing a collar and identification.  Because he was so scared of approaching cars that he hunkered down in the tall grass and weeds until each car had passed by, it was obvious that he hadn't voluntarily elected to be roadside; i.e., it was apparent that he had been dumped where he was "stranded" beside the road.
 
Bernard wasn't a very "gutsy" guy when his foster mom picked him up.  Although he did come part of the way to her when she baby talked him, he did so in a half crouch.  And, when they arrived home a couple of hours later, he was very, very, VERY reluctant to fraternize with the other dogs...and certainly not with the cats for goodness sakes.  The first dog he "cottoned up to" in his foster home was Lucky, who is the favorite dog of all the dogs in residence because he constantly defleas anybody near him.  While Lucky is still Bernie's favorite friend and he would follow him into the flames of Satan's domain, he has become friendly and playful with all of the other dogs in his foster home as well.
 
While it is anticipated that Bernie's adopter will be able to afford flea prevention (which his foster mom cannot afford to provide for the MANY dogs in her care), Bernie would be very happy to have Lucky accompany him into his adoptive home or to at least have another friendly family dog to groom on him.
 
With the cats, Bernie is a little more reserved.  While he no longer frowns with ears flattened backward in fear of cats, he only sniffs the air when one of them is near or rubs up against him.  Prophecy:  He is ready made for becoming the best friend of a dog-friendly cat in his future.
 
His foster mom named this beautiful boy Bernard because of the fact that he looks like a small version of a Saint Bernard.  However, she usually calls him Bernie; and he responds to either moniker.  He has GORGEOUS amber eyes.  And, while Bernie resembles several "exotic" breeds, he is a very unique fellow.  One of his unique traits is that he likes to lie Sphinx style but with his rear legs STRAIGHT out behind him.  And, if possible, he is always lying in the vicinity of his favorite buddy Lucky in case Lucky is feeling the inclination to deflea (mouth massage) him.  Oooh, ahhhhhh !  He would be very lonely (and most likely unhappy) without a canine buddy.
 
On 5/24/10, Bernie weighed 49.4 lbs. and was estimated to be about one year of age.  He was still intact...but not for long !  Although Bernie tested negative for heartworms during his initial veterinary visit, the same blood test revealed him to be positive for E. Canis (Erhlichia).  So Bernie was put on 250 mg of the antibiotic Doxycycline twice a day for 30 days to eliminate the Erhlichia. Erhlichia is commonly referred to as tick fever because it is transmitted by the Brown Dog Tick if the tick has fed on an animal infected with Erhlichia.  Erhlichia causes anemia and low blood platelets and can be fatal if not treated.  Therefore, Bernie's castration was delayed until 6/29/10 when the Erhlichia had been arrested.
 
Standing 21" tall (height from the floor to the top of his shoulders) with a torso of the same length (21" from the base of his neck to the base of his tail), Bernie weighed 55.93 lbs. as of 6/3/15.
 
Obedience training is always recommended for bonding and safety's sake for any new canine addition to a family, and this smart boy should make an excellent student.  He learned his [new] name quickly and has become increasingly velcroed to his human and animal "family."  Both are signs of a readiness to please.
 
This gentle-natured boy undoubtedly would enjoy the companionship of gentle, elementary school aged human siblings in his adoptive family.  Participating in Bernie's training classes would be an excellent forum for teaching children the virtues of non-drug, non-sex related activities for recreation, as well as for forming a strong basis for bonding with their new canine family member.

Having been started on heartworm preventative, vaccinated, and neutered, Bernard is ready to join a permanent family to share his life, love, fun, and happy memories for many years to come.
 
CALL THIS HANDSOME FELLOW BERNARD OR CALL HIM BERNIE, JUST CALL HIM A BELOVED FAMILY MEMBER.

*UP FOR ADOPTION***  After working with Wally and having him live with me for 6+ months, this boy is ready for his forever home!  His ideal home MUST have Aussie experience, physical fenced yard, no kids (he has found that he really enjoys the less hectic lifestyle), NO other dogs.  He will thrive in a home with positive leadership and someone that enjoys having him do the numerous obedience commands and playing frisbee or throwing a tennis ball, but also will be an amazing Companion.  He loves to be with his person, inside or out.  Wally is crate trained, house trained, is rock solid with Sit, Down, Stay, Look, Come, Waits for his food until released, Waits to go out the door, Walks well on leash, Rides amazing in the car.
What Wally doesn't do well with is fireworks, loud truck noises, lots of hectic action (this boy is 100% Aussie and if the energy is high, he goes into Aussie herding mode), he cannot be placed in a home with other dogs or where dogs will be visiting, he's not a candidate for dog parks or doggy daycare. 
Wally is 4 yo, neutered, up-to-date on vaccinations and microchipped and has been tested for the MDR-1 Mutant gene.  Wally is fostered in Plainwell, MI on the west side of the state.  If interested in meeting Wally, please contact Morna at:  morna_merkler@hotmail.com

You can fill out an adoption application online on our official website.** Be sure to watch LizBeth's video's below so you can see how very kind & gentle she is ***
Let me tell you about this young girl. She is a Spaniel/Hound mix, petite (only 30 lbs) sweet, gentle little girl. LizBeth was in a shelter in KY & she had been so badly abused that she would fall to the floor & roll over in total submission. She has been here with me now for several months & she has come a very long way. She lives in my home & has found her spot on my sofa or chair where she can finally feel totally safe.
I liken what these dogs have been thru as PTSD in humans. What I find most amazing about dogs who have been literally beaten by sub-humans â inexplicitly --- they are still capable of loving people even though no one has ever shown them affection or kindness. When LizBeth arrived & for quite some time her ears were flat down. One of my best feelings about being a foster mom is I get to see them feel well enough mentally that their ears pop straight up. Now, of course, this only with dogs whose ears were meant to be straight up. When a dogâs spirit has been crushed their ears go down but they pop-up as LizBeth has when she is finally about to be the dog she was meant to be ................ She's become very affectionate, gives me tiny little butterfly kisses of gratitude. She will require her adoptive family to have had experience with dogs who have been abused like her. She will improve day by day, month by month, but there is a chance she may always be afraid when meeting new people. She is not a fear-biter at all â she just falls to the ground when she scared. If you can see how lovely she is & think she might be the kind of girl you would love to bring into your life, be sure to read our adoption requirementâs & if you can meet or exceed them you can apply online at our website.

Jake's approximate birth date is April 21, 2005. He weighs approximately 13 lbs. He is neutered, vaccinated, and has tested negative for heartworm/lyme's disease. He has also received dental care and he has a registered microchip.

Jake has a sad story that is told way too often in rescue. After living his entire life with an owner who he loved, he found himself surrendered to a shelter when he could no longer be cared for. This 'shelter' deemed him 'unadoptable' and he was scheduled for euthanasia. Is Jake a young scrappy puppy? No. Does he have age related health issues? Yes. Does he sometime feel like a crabby old man? Yep. Should this make him 'unadoptable'? ABSOLUTELY NOT!!! Jake did not deserve to have his life end scared and alone in a shelter with strangers. He is safe in rescue now and is eagerly waiting for a new family to find him. One that won't desert him and promises to be there to the end.

Jake is a sweet little guy who loves to be with his people and will jump into any available lap. He loves to be pet and is excited for belly rubs. He is fine with most other dogs close to his size, but can be a little crabby with bigger dogs sometimes. He would likely enjoy having a home to his own where he could be the center of attention! He does love to harass kittens, but may do well with a dog savvy cat after he learns that they won't be a game of chase! He sleeps quietly in his kennel overnight, but may enjoy to share a bed with his new family.

Jake has age related health issues. He has had a dental procedure with tooth extractions. He is completely healed from that procedure and eagerly eats his dry food... although he really enjoys a treat of canned food! He seems to have some hearing and sight deficits typically of aging dogs. At this time, we believe that sight issues may be causing some type of anxiety as the sun sets. Maybe due to shadows? He seems to be a little bothered by movement of people or animals that are over his head. Because of this, he is being crated after dinner until darkness sets in and he is just fine with that! He will need to go to a family with no young children and one who is willing to work with this evening mystery!

Don't let Jake's age fool you... he loves to be active and explore! He does like to run around free in the yard, so a physical fence is required. NO invisible fencing is permitted.

If you are interested in meeting or adopting Jake, please complete an adoption application at: www.savingtails.net

*Due to the STAR adoption process and the continuing support of our rescue animals, STAR does not do adoptions outside of a 60 mile radius of the Twin Cities area.

Saving Tails Animal Rescue (STAR) is a 501(c)3 registered no-kill, non profit animal rescue. All animals are placed in loving foster homes until their forever family finds them. Because there is not a physical shelter location, foster homes are needed to help rescue local animals who are in danger of euthanasia. HI! My name is Kanzi and I need a foster/permanent home where someone is there during most of the day. 

Turn ons: cuddles, any food. ANY food, walks, car rides, nylabones, and a soft cuddly couch and bed to curl up on with my selected human. I love to explore places. 

I also enjoy eating toilet paper (you need to close the bathroom door or I will have fun pulling down the roll), kleenex, napkins (any paper product really is delicious). 

My breed can be independent in thought and I'll listen when I am ready or when you have a treat! Like a cat (or a Basenji), I have the ability to hop up on a stool by the Kitchen Island for you to serve me and also can hop on a table. 

Turn offs: negative reinforcement (positive reinforcements/treats/love only please), being left alone for any long period of time. A bored Basenji is a scary thing. Plus I will howl if I am left alone and isolated. I need companionship to thrive, whether human or canine.  I really do want to be your best bud and go everywhere and do everything with you. I want to explore, meet new people, be the center of your world. I'll even go to obedience training with you so we can bond! 

I just celebrated my 8th birthday in doggy daycare!  Iwas born on Christmas Eve, 2009. I have a very prestigious bloodline of  Kibushi. My daddy was a descendant of Get Sirius who was from Avongara Gangura of the Congo. I'm a magical little girl who could be a movie star!

I am a very sweet girl but as with any Basenji, I can be selective at times with who I wants to buddy up with dog wise. I prefer male companionship, but I am OK  with most other dogs. I am used to living in rescue with different dogs always coming in and out. There is only one dog I don't like which is why I need my own home.  The dog I don't like is a permanent rescue bonded with another resident of the household. But I have been evaluated to be in a group in doggy daycare and I am socialized weekly with my friends at Barkefellers!

I like going to doggy daycare but I really don't interact with the other dogs as much hang out with the staff or explore. I don't need there to be another dog  in the household but would probably do just fine with one.

Really I loves and thrive on human attention. I love new adventures also. I want to live my life to the fullest! 

I want someone home with me most of the time, or to go to daycare or with you!  I really will howl or cry if left isolated and alone too often. I need companionship and I don't want to be lonely.  Plus, left to my own devices I would get into trouble I'm sure if I was bored. Central Indiana is preferred so the rescue can keep tabs on me and visit me but all applications will be reviewed to determine the best fit and home for me.

I haven't lived with children but I love when they pet me on walks. I think I'd do great with with older kids who would respect her and not man-handle her. 

If interested in becoming my new best friend,  please complete the preliminary application found here if you are still interested after doing some research on my breed via google search etc.   https://secure.mailjol.net/allforms/u/3a7aa268.php

The NAWS Dog Adoption Program operates as a rescue versus a shelter. We believe in matching the right dog with the appropriate family based on each specific dog or familyâs needs. This cannot be achieved if people stop by unexpectedly to meet our dogs. Please e-mail Stacy@NAWSUS.org to set up a day and time to meet with Tim or Heather, (our dog adoption counselors), and our potential adoptees. Thank you!!

Walker Dan is a highly intelligent, super sweet, young boy.  He is about 10 months old.  Walker Dan gets along with other dogs, and loves people.  He is obedient and willing to learn.  Walker Dan was picked up as a stray in rural Oklahoma and ended up in a high kill shelter.  We  help rural dogs where there is little to no hope of getting out of a shelter alive.  We have been placing wonderful dogs in great homes across the country.  Our dogs are completely vetted, heart worm tested, and temperament tested, and placed in foster homes until a permanent home is found.  Walker Dan is active and playful.  He is a working class dog so should have plenty of activity.  He is also loving and very affectionate.  He is great with children, and good on a leash.  He has also been trained off leash. This sweet boy is ready to find his place in the sun.  Our fee is $275 which includes all his vetting, and transport to his final destination.  We offer a trial period and guarantee our dogs.  If not a good fit, we take them back.  But, to date, no one has wanted to return a dog.  We are careful in our placement.  These lost rural dogs are our family, and Walker Dan will make the right family complete.

Ask yourself some questions before you consider bringing a new dog home.   1.  Am I ready for a LIFE LONG commitment?  2. Am I prepared for a rowdy puppy?  3. Am I prepared to potty train?   4.
