At roughly 18 months old, 51 lbs- Ollie is the epitome of a sweet puppy.We suspect he is a Border Collie/Basset Hound mix. His loving demeanor is expressed continuously in wanting to be around his 2 legged or 4 legged friends. Ollie loves to snuggle and is quick to show affection. Ollie plays well with other dogs but cats are another matter. His curious nature shines through which makes him chase cats, this has not been a huge issue for us but is of concern.

Ollie shows some tendencies of BCs but others have not been observed. Ollie is low to medium energy, with bursts of puppy energy intermittently. Minimal nipping and herding, loud sounds do not scare him (but of interest), he does not chase vehicles from what we have experienced- but is fast to catch a scent. He will pull somewhat on leashed walks and has not been off leash, unless in a fenced in area.

His potty breaks are timed or done after drinking a lot of water or eating (2x's a day) but he's still in the process of learning how to notify us when he needs to go outside. He does well in his crate for short periods of time and at night. One must be careful while driving as Ollie can get car sick if fast turns happen. Ollie will also tend to go through open doors, so he must be monitored closely. Ollie has done exceptionally well with new commands and shows the interest and ability to learn quickly and please his owners.

It has been a pleasure and a privilege to bring Ollie into our home. Ollie is looking for his forever home with people that can shower him with love and attention, which in turn will be readily reciprocated.

Rocky is a 1-2 year old Treeing Walker Coonhound mix. He weighs around 52 lbs and is at a good weight. He was rescued from a dog shelter in southern OH. Rocky was so shy that they asked for help where he could be in a foster home. Rocky had gone to their prison program and was trained by the inmates and really learned his stuff but still was remaining very shy. He is crate trained and knows his basic commands. Rocky is also housetrained and rides great in the car. He gets along great with dogs but should not go to a home with any cats. We believe he will be excellent with respectful children. Rocky would love a home with a child or two to keep him busy and a secure fenced in yard. The fenced in yard is a must for him and we would like an adopter to be an active person who will walk him daily and maybe do some hiking. Rocky is an excellent boy and is really well behaved but he is not a couch potato. If exercised properly, he will relax and nap with the best of them. If interested in Rocky, please e-mail hartmanshounds@gmail.com or call Peggy @ 440-452-1619. 4/10/18 9:24 PM

Meet Buford the regal beagle! He is just a gentle older fellow who would appreciate a calm and quiet home to call his own. He doesn't ask for too much, just a little love and a cozy place to nap! Come meet Buford today! Buford has heartworm which means that this dog has parasitic worms in the right ventricle of the heart and nearby blood vessels. Heartworm is transmitted from one dog to another by mosquitoes and can be easily prevented using monthly heartworm preventative, but once the disease is contracted the treatment process can be quite intensive. Buford will need to remain sedentary with minimal activity during the treatment process to ensure a healthy recovery. There is additional information on heartworm disease and treatment available at our Adoption Desk.

PLEASE READ BELOW IF INTERESTED IN THIS DOG! 

IF YOU ARE SEEING THIS LISTING, THEN THE DOG IS STILL AVAILABLE AND WE ARE PROCESSING INQUIRIES FOR ITS NEW HOME. We remove them immediately once we have stopped taking inquiries and have a pending home.

PLEASE FOLLOW THE DIRECTIONS BELOW TO BE CONSIDERED. Please provide a contact phone number! Once we narrow down to the top three candidates, we usually call them to discuss details and then make our choice to meet the dog. Those who send no information about your home or family, or just ask is the dog available, how much, or how old will not be answered. All of that information is listed here and unfortunately, due to the volume of inquiries asking those basic questions, we are unable to answer all of the emails and texts. We also get a lot of people who send in the basic question because of the cute factor and really are not ready to adopt yet.  Please make sure that all of your household members are ready to adopt before pursuing adoption.

We understand that some of this is due to the new Petfinder format with their basic question at the bottom and apologize for that. In addition we are getting duplicates from most people because of confusion with Petfinder's new system which is making it difficult to tell if your inquiry was sent to us. Also the Petfinder new system asks for a zip code or location but does not forward that to us so we cannot tell your location. We do not fly our animals so please make sure that you are able to drive to Michigan if you are interested in one of our pets.  We are getting a lot of complaints from prospective homes trying to navigate Petfinder's new system and requests from several who enjoyed the various sections of our previous home page.  We cannot do anything about the changes to the format and the removal of the information on our home page, etc. Many people are simply sending their information to us directly at petangels@gmail.com or via text or voicemail to 734-645-7705 which may be a simpler solution at this point.

Posted 4-9-18:

Tom and Jerry are about 6 months old and looking for homes to love them forever. They are beagle and boston terrier mixes ("Boggle" for those who like to  call mutts by their "designer" names).   They are about 6 months and could be up to 20 pounds full grown.    They are medium to high energy and Tom can be dominant with other animals.     Tom will need someone with training experience.  They can be separated.  

They have been using pee pads some and will need further work on housebreaking.  They are pretty well crate trained.

If interested in adopting, please call or text 734-645-7705 and leave your name, location, brief summary of family, work hours, dog experience, training and exercise plans, and a phone contact number. 

Adoption fee is $395 each (cash with receipt or Paypal). They are neutered and shots are completed including their first rabies.

Neptune is a 1 year old mountain cur/ possibly beagle mix. He is a total sweetheart. He can be hesitant with some men but warms up. One of his favorite things is snuggling with his foster dad. He is good with otuer dogs and is pretty playful. He hasnt been around cats but is pretty submissive. He is pretty much potty trained but could use a bit more training on consistency. He is neutered, up to date on vaccines, heartworm negative, and microchipped. He has been treated for worms and has had a fecal test done. He can be a bit skittish so may be better with older or calmer children. Walks well on a leash and likes car rides. If you would like to see kore pictures and updates you can check him out on our facebook page facebook.com/allforkarmaanimalrescue. To apply to adopt Neptune please go to our website at www.allforkarmaanimalrescue.com. his adoption donation to the rescue is $260

Mikey was adopted 7 years ago as a companion for another Beagle.  They had a ball together.  But eventually, an infant joined the family and Mikey's nose was out of joint,  But when the little one started walking around the house, it proved too much for Mikey.  So his family asked us to find him a new home without young children.  Mikey is good with other dogs (although he does play hard) and loves to be hugged and cuddled.  He is good in the house, so shouldn't need to be crated. Another playful dog would be great.  Being a hound, his nose will get him in trouble if he does not have a fenced yard.  Does your place sound like a good place for Mikey to start over?  Contact Pat, his foster mom, at 248-860-5488 or dogladyffr@yahoo.com

Freckles owner ran into financial hardship and was about to lose his home and have to live in his car.  After several shelters refused to take his dog,  (they would only euthanize him - age 14) he turned to his vet.  His vet made several calls, hoping to find him a home.   Furry Friends took him in.  He is a very sweet, laid back, calm old guy.  He loves to run in the yard, sleep in the sun, and play gently with the other dogs.  Can you find a spot in your home and heart to take in this senior fella to live out his life ?


For more information, contact his foster mom, Pat, at  248 860 5688  or at  dogladyffr@yahoo.com

Abby came to us when her mom entered a nursing home and couldn't bring her along.  She loves everyone and gives kisses to all.  She is great with most dogs and well behaved.  She does have several medical issues - occasional seizures and eye issues.  She requires daily pills and eye drops for those issues..  A fenced yard is required, since Beagle's noses tend to get them in trouble.  She loves attention and would love to cuddle.  

For more information, contact her foster mom, Pat, at 248 860 5688  or at  dogladyffr@yahoo.com

Lucy is a sweet little girl who is as affectionate as can be. She enjoys the company of other dogs, loves children and adults and will make a wonderful loving addition to a family.  She is currently working on her housetraining, but is a smart girl and should pick it up quickly.  She loves to cuddle, loves to play and just wants to spend time with a family of her own.
Birth Date: 07/10/2017

Bubba was surrendered to Pug Luv because his owner did not have time for him.  He was neutered and has been brought up to date on Rabies, DHLLP, Bordetella, heart worm and fecal checked and a blood panel done.  He is good with children and other dogs.  He is house trained and loves children.

If you are interested in adopting Bubba or any of the dogs currently with Pug Luv, go to michiganpugrescue.com, click on the Adopt/Foster tab on the left of the home page, download, print, complete and submit an Application for Adoption to begin the adoption process.

All updates on Bubba will be posted to his web page at michiganpugrescue.com

Tycho is 2 years old. He needs a patient adopter who will help him gain confidence, get him further training, and see him for the wonderful dog he can be. Tycho is fearful and protective  when strangers come into his house. It takes him a bit to warm up to new people, but once he does, he is a cuddle bug! He loves to walk and play, but also enjoys laying around. His favorite spot is on top of the couch. He is great in the car. Tycho will make a great pet for the right person!

Abbey is an approximately 7-8 year old Beagle mix.  She weighs 42 lbs so is a nice medium sized dog.   She is friendly and gentle when meeting new people and is great with kids!
 
She is the only dog in her foster Mom's house so it is unknown at this time how she would get along with another dog in the house. She has shown no aggression to the neighbor's dogs so she will probably be fine with a canine companion.  Any prospective adopter with a dog currently in the home should plan on bringing the dog with them to meet Abbey.
 
Abbey is housebroken. She keeps her crate clean when left alone in it for 2-3 hours. She also does fine not crated.  She is active and energetic. Daily walks or runs at a doggie park would suit her well.
 
Abbey is current on vaccinations, tested negative for heartworm disease and is on monthly heartworm preventative and Frontline Plus. She has also had a dental cleaning.
 
If interested in adopting Abbey through Silver Lake Animal Rescue League, please fill out our online application at http://www.silverlake.petfinder.com and send completed application to slarl@yahoo.com or to cherylberk7@aol.com.  Call foster Mom Cheryl at 248-247-5043 for further information.
 

Applications can be found on our website:  www.silverlake.petfinder.com

Chance, formerly known as Rommie, came into our rescue in August of 2017.  He was adopted in the fall but has been returned because his family feels he needs more exercise and attention than they can give him.  Chance is already neutered, current on shots, microchipped and has been through a basic dog training course at Training Buddies.

Chance has a lot of energy so the best home for him would be one with a fenced yard and possibly a stay-at-home parent or someone who does not work long hours.  He really needs to run and burn off some of his energy.  He would do best with kids 10 and older.  Although he only weighs 32 pounds he is too much for younger children.  Chance also needs someone with dog experience who is willing to continue to work with him.  His adoption fee is $225 with an approved application.

If you are interested in adopting Chance, please contact Best Buddy Pet Rescue at (248) 622-6097 or complete an online adoption application at:  https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1epZyyuSO_T4M9sDi2pu5kSTFBpCLl0Aw7CilojC1z3s/viewform

Meet Darla, a Jack Russell Terrier/Beagle mix.   Darla is 3 years old and weighs approximately 30-35 pounds.  She came from a hoarding situation as a puppy.  She was adopted from us as a puppy and has just been returned after 3 years.  she is shy when meeting new people but seems to warm up really fast.  She is good with kids 7 years old and up.  She has not been around kids younger than 7 years old.  When she was returned we were told she needed work on house training but her foster mom hasn't had any issues as long as she is taken out on a regular basis.  She is spayed and up to date on shots.  Darla is pretty quiet and seems content to lay by people.  Her adoption fee is $225 with an approved application. 

If you are interested in adopting, please contact Best Buddy Pet Rescue at (248) 622-6097 or complete an online adoption application at:  https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1epZyyuSO_T4M9sDi2pu5kSTFBpCLl0Aw7CilojC1z3s/viewform

I AM AVAILABLE FOR ADOPTION, HOWEVER DUE TO MY SITUATION MY ADOPTION WILL HAVE TO BE FACILITATED THROUGH A RESCUE ORGANIZATION. PLEASE SEE THE FRONT DESK STAFF FOR MORE INFORMATION. The following descriptions describe behaviors that were observed during testing and/or veterinary examination. This is Roscoe! Roscoe served a 10 day bite quarantine for an incident with an infant. The previous owner stated that the child was hanging on the dog when this had happened. We have had the opportunity to evaluate Roscoe and still believe he could be re-homed with the disclaimer that he has bitten in the past. To set him up for success Roscoe should not have children in his company. Besides his bite history Roscoe is an overall great dog! He would make a great companion to get out and go on adventures with. His breed usually have great noses and enjoy smelling new things and it will be important to keep his mind occupied so that he doesn't become too bored and get into mischief. Roscoe has been sporting a harness lately because he's been having problems breathing while he is on a collar. We recommend only utilizing the harness when going for walks. Dog relationships can be just as complex and complicated as human relationships at times. We recommend separating any new additions in the home while unsupervised until a comfortable relationship has been established. Home FurEver is a non-profit foster based canine rescue seeking foster parents, volunteers and donations. Please see our website for more information.
 
Please note that Home FurEver does not post applications on line. We will receive all applications in person at local adoption events in order to conduct an in-person interview.  All members of the household should be present for the application and interview process. All applicants require a home inspection and vet check - Please note that we cannot drive more than an hour to do a home inspection.  We do require a fenced back yard for all bully breeds.  Some dogs may require households with children over a certain age.

Ask yourself some questions before you consider bringing a new dog home.   1.  Am I ready for a LIFE LONG commitment?  2. Am I prepared for a rowdy puppy?  3. Am I prepared to potty train?   4. Is this the right breed for me or my family?  5. Can I afford the food and vet care for this dog?  6. Is it best to have a totally fenced yard?  7. Will I make a commitment to obedience training?

The class clown and a LOT of dogDate into Rescue: 10/25/2017

Reason for being in rescue: Pulled from NC shelter, originally found as a stray
Foster location: Dreamweaver Farms, Pacolet SC
Special Needs? Experienced owners only, this is a LOT of dog. Bear is highly heartworm positive (HW+). He will be sent home with a year supply of heartworm medication. He is being treated with a method called the slow kill treatment. He takes a monthly Ivermectin based heartworm preventative and needs to be re-tested for heartworms every 6 months. Once he tests negative, then he can take any kind of heartworm preventative; he is not restricted to Ivermectin based only. PLEASE NOTE our heartworm positive dogs MUST be kept on this method of treatment. Make sure to talk with you vet about this method before submitting an application.

Weight: Estimated 55 lb
Height: Estimated 24 in at the shoulder Spayed/Neutered: Yes
Spayed/Neutered: Yes

Adoption Fee: $200

Fence needed? Yes, he needs room to run and play.

What kind of home would be best for me? Bear will need an active home with owners that are willing to work out his puppy like quirks.

What is my personality like? Oh Bear! He is a character! A sweet boy with tons of potential with the correct family. He was found as a stray in North Carolina and taken to a local shelter. When we got the call for this boy, we could not turn him away.. look at that sweet scruffy face! Bear is very playful and silly and will keep you on your toes. You will never be bored or lonely. At first he didn't like a leash on him, but he is getting used to it. He still needs practice because of his pulling. When he gets excited, he does mouth at you. Don't be alarmed! We call them love bites. With a good smelling treat you can make him sit as long as nothing else is going on. He will even stay as you walk back a few steps again all of this for his favorite thing in the world... treats! Although, If he's wanting to run you can't get his attention unless you put a treat in his face. When Bear first arrived at the farm the caregivers were a little apprehensive of him. He wouldn't let you leash him or even touch his neck. But he has quickly overcome those hurdles in just 2 short weeks! With the right home he would make a great dog, but he is a lot of dog and he needs someone who enjoys training and is consistent and firm. We can't emphasis this enough - he is a LOT of dog. Bear has come a very long way. He is a lot of dog and sometimes overwhelms other dogs.

How do I act when I first meet new people? Friendly

Other Tips and Tidbits: He can be dog reactive, so a meet and greet with other dogs is a must.

House trained? Dogs can be house trained if they are in the right environment and are allowed to follow a schedule as long as a physical reason doesn't keep them from being trained. A dog house trained in my home may not be in yours. We will help you teach your new dog this necessary skill and based on your schedule.

Please note - we do not ship dogs. If you are interested in adopting, please take a look at the distance between the foster home location and your location and make sure you are willing to make that trip. Most of our dogs are at our farm in Pacolet, South Carolina.

To apply, please visit our webpage at www.carolinapoodlerescue.org and visit the tab on the left that directions you to the online application.

Please note that when screening applications, we look at the entire home and then make suggestions based on what would be a good fit for your home. You are not being screened for a specific dog although we are looking to see what type of dog interests you - poodles or non poodles, color, age, etc. Others here may be a better fit for you. It is very difficult to get to know a living animal from a picture and a short description. Since we are constantly getting in new dogs, this may be a dog not in our listings yet. We want you to be very happy with your new companion and will make suggestions based on what you tell us about you.

Thank you for considering CPR.

Jerry once had a home. His previous owner had run away to escape the many debts he owed as a result of gambling. Without the owner taking dogs with him, Jerry was deserted in an empty house, no food and no water, until later he was found weak by the neighbors. We donât want to think of any excuse. It was heartbreaking for our rescuers on that day to witness these meek and gentle creatures, starved and all by themselves, lying on the ground waiting. Perhaps Jerry was missing his owner, but he didn't know that his owner was not coming back anymore. Our rescuers took Jerry to the vet. He was in a very poor condition; the doctor said he had suffered from a long-term starvation and dehydration.

He was hospitalized to ensure he would be well taken care of. Jerry is a bright boy. He loves to play with the other dogs from his foster family. He also likes to approach everyone with curiosity. Jerry enjoys exploring the outside world and likes to tag along in every human activity. He likes to be teased and encouraged; he would twist his bum happily. Such a funny and playful dog! Jerry had been in a vet clinic for some time, but now his foster mom has given him so much love and kept him company. We think he wishes everyone could hug him and hold him. Jerry is ready to find a forever home. It is our sincere hope that someone will give him a chance and provide him with a happy and secure home.

Please open your heart and your sweet home. If you are interested in Jerry, or want to help him. Please contact us.

City Dogs Rescue & City Kitties is a foster based rescue in Washington, DC. We do not have a shelter. We focus on local adoptions in DC and the metro area of Maryland and Virginia. CDR&CK has a thorough adoption process in order to find the best possible fit for each of our dogs and cats (we do not operate under a first-come, first served model).

Upon accepting a new cat or dog into the organization, we provide a basic vet visit that includes necessary vaccinations, disease screenings, deworming, microchips, and spay/neuter (unless specified). We do not provide a comprehensive medical exam prior to adoption. As a result, sickness, injury, and disability may exist unbeknownst to CDR&CK. City Dogs Rescue & City Kitties is not responsible for payment of any vet care, including known and unknown medical conditions once a cat or dog is adopted from us. Dog specific: Rabies, DHPP, Bordatella vaccines. They are tested for HW, Lyme, Ehrlichia, Anaplasmosis.

Most cats and dogs will have a house training accident in the initial days in their new home and we cannot guarantee any pet is housebroken or crate trained.

We also update our Facebook page daily with new cats and dogs.

STAR is a foster-based rescue. All our rescue animals stay in foster homes until adoption. We do not have a central facility. If you want to meet any of our adoptables please submit an application.

SPONSORED FEE: Kasey's Adoption Fee has been sponsored.

Hi, my name is Kasey. I came into my foster home emaciated, full of parasites, with an extremely bad UTI. It's taken me awhile to get back to health, but I'm doing so much better! We don't know how long I actually had a UTI that was left untreated, but due to this, I do leak urine. We are currently still working along side the vet to see if this will be a life long issue.

I was very loving and friendly when I came into my foster home, but I was very withdrawn. I have come so far! I am still skittish because of some things that must have happened to me in my past. I don't care for garbage trucks, or thunder, and when my 10 year old human brother gets rowdy with his toy weapons and such, I get very nervous. However, I have never growled or attempted to bite anyone. I just go hide by my foster Mom when I get nervous or scared.

I love to play with my foster sister who is an Airedale Terrier. We play great together and have a lot of fun! We are great buddies! I would love a home with a very friendly buddy that gets along with everyone as I do.

I really do need a fenced yard. I do have greyhound in me, and if I got loose, I would probably make it very far away in a short time! I walk pretty well on a leash, and I will go potty on leash. I also need to have a martingale collar kept on me, because like a greyhound, I can slip a collar easily. My neck is wider than my head.

I didn't really care for the crate for a long time. Maybe this was because of being stuck in the cage at animal control. My foster Mom has worked with me, and I am much better. I am crated when the family leaves the house. At night, I will sleep on my dog bed, on the bedroom floor all night long with no problems.

I am very smart! I already knew how to sit,lay down, and shake. My foster Mom says that someone could probably train me to do much more!

I have MANY greyhound traits! If you've ever been around a greyhound, when you meet me, you'll see exactly what I mean! My Mom thinks my most prominent Belgian Malinois trait is my bond to one person in the home. Which is my foster Mom! Don't get me wrong, I love everyone else too, she just happens to be my favorite! Oh, and I have a big, tuff bark! I will surely scare someone away if you need me to! I do like to be a bit bossy to my Airedale sister sometimes. If she starts barking, I will go put her in her place. I sound like I'm being mean to her, but I don't hurt her, I just try to tell her to knock it off! Luckily, she's as friendly as she is, and just tries to ignore me. Mom gets after me when I do this, and I'm getting a bit better with it.

I don't think I would like a very loud and busy house. When it gets like that here sometimes, I get very nervous and worried. Mom thinks that maybe I was in a home with a lot of fighting and violence. Sometimes I'm not sure if people are playing or fighting, and it makes me very scared. Mom reassures me that everything is OK, and makes everyone calm down.

Oh, I forgot to mention. Mom stays at home! I'm lucky because now that my big sister is off to college, and my 10 year old brother is back in school, I get a lot of time with Mom! I don't have to go in that crate too often!

So far, I've been great with dogs my size and smaller dogs, we aren't sure about cats, because we don't have any. Mom thinks I would probably be OK, but could possibly need some correction.

When we go on car rides, I ride VERY well. In fact, I usually lay down and go to sleep!

If you want to know more about me, ask Mom, she knows a lot about me!

***If you have zero working dog experience, stop reading. This dog is not for you.*** 

Delaney is stunning, yes, however she is a working dog and is very busy. She has a high prey drive and no off switch. That said, she is very gentle as only a 10 month old puppy can be. She is eager to please, very sensitive, and super smart. She is tentative of new situations and people, so continued socialization is a must. 

Delaney was purchased as a tiny puppy, and left to her own devices. Many dogs who are working dogs, are dumped when people realize the level of proper management thatâs involved in owning one. This breed is not for everyone. Please do your research prior to applying to adopt. 

We suspect Delaney was either left outside, or locked away in a bedroom somewhere, and then dumped at the shelter when she became too much to handle. She was afraid of everything when arriving in her foster home. The ceiling fans, heat running, exhaust fans, television and every day noises sent her into a tizzy. She hated being outside alone, and is just now starting to realize that she will be let back in. These are things that time will correct, but her adopter MUST be patient and kind while she gets acclimated to her new home. 

Delaney needs a confident handler, but one who will not try to strong arm her. Unlike many other working breeds who often work well under strong personality types, she does NOT respond well to gruff techniques. She does not like being yelled at, leash corrected or grabbed. Itâs obvious these things have happened to her in the past. She is very compliant and works best with a gentle hand. We continue to teach her that the âboogeymanâ isnât after her. She is a work in progress. 

She is a dream on leash, crate trained and does awesome with other dogs. She lives with dog savvy cats who have taken to playing chase with her, so sensitive kitties need not apply. She is a petite 60lbs, but is still filling out. She will be around 70lbs at maturity. 

Adoption fee $350 (all MVPC dogs are heartworm-tested, completely vetted, spayed/neutered and microchipped) 

INQUIRIES: ALL inquiries begin with a submitted adoption application, which is found on our website, www.miamivalleypitcrew.com. We do not adopt to individuals under the age of 25. 

DO NOT: USE THE PETFINDER CONTACT/ADOPT BUTTONS--we are unable to monitor those. 

PLEASE NOTE: We are volunteer based and a home visit is required; Delaney is a candidate for the Dayton, OH area only. Thank you for your understanding!

Prancer is a wonderful girl who is 8 years young and very well-traveled. Prancer was originally a stray in Paris where her owners found her as a puppy. They took Prancer in and gave her a loving home and the experience of traveling many countries with them. Unfortunately like many Malinois and Malinois mixes Prancer valued her personal space and didnât like meeting new people or having to tolerate other dogs. Her owners allowed Prancer to become quite the diva however when they were then asked to relocate to Germany Prancer was unable to pass customs into the country. The owners did everything they could but in the end had to surrender Prancer to us in the hopes of finding her a new home. 

Prancer is a wonderful girl who is still very active and energetic. Like most Malinois Prancer needs firm boundaries set around her behavior. Since arriving with us Prancer has become better about being handled by multiple people but we would not suggest her for a home with small children or lots of activity in and out of the house. Prancer isnât the type of dog who likes to be cuddled or fussed over. She values having a job or activity â even if it is just lying on the bed â and appreciates a no-nonsense attitude. Prancer has also become accustom to other dogs and does really well with the other dogs. 

Again she is a very no-nonsense dog and will tell the younger dogs to leave her alone sometimes but will also play with them at times. Prancer is above all a very loyal dog and once you have gained her trust and loyalty you couldnât ask for a better dog. Prancer is searching for a home who understands and appreciates her Malinois characteristics and will give her the love she deserves into her golden years.

If you have any questions about Prancer, or would like an application, please contact us at Tierhavenrescue@gmail.com.

Aeron is living in Greeneville, TN, and his adopter must come to this location to pick him up.

Aeron is now two and we are finally starting to see some calmer behavior out of him.  This boy has been ADHD on speed since he completed his vaccinations.

He chews anything that isn't nailed down, but even that is slowing down.  He carefully shops the garage for things to destroy, and is slowly learning that my library is definitely off limits.  I currently have about $200.00 worth of books to hunt their replacements because he decided to be a literary critic one morning.

Aeron is tall, weighs just under 70# because he hasn't been neutered yet.  He underwent two gastric surgeries within the first 20 weeks of his life over swallowing a squeaker whole when he was 8 weeks old.

Consequently he was crated for sixteen weeks and only allowed to be leash walked during the most important socialization time of his life.

Aeron lacks social skills.  He will jump on other dogs, play with some dogs until whatever they are playing with becomes extremely important to him, then he will turn on aggression to get it back.  Sigh, this is a trial, and it is totally due to his first sixteen weeks of live not being what they should have been.

Aeron is too boisterous for a family with children, and would destroy all toys left laying around just to entertain himself.

He loves sleeve work, but lacks any prey drive.  Won't chase a ball, you threw it, you go get it.

Needless to say, Aeron needs a very special home where he can sleep in your bed with you, be allowed to eat the woodwork on the odd day, share your recliner, (you will need one of those massive recliner types...), and totally love and adore his person.

He loves car rides, and will hop in uninvited, knocking you aside in the process.  If you leave a window down, he will attempt to get in through the opening.

I will try to get new photo's up of him in the near future, but we lack help at the rescue.

You can apply for Aeron at:
http://www.greenepets.org/adoption-application.html
